If anything it improves control by absorbing chatter that would bounce your hands around. That said, there is an alternative. https://canecreek.com/product/eesilk-stem/

data.text: I'm a heavy dude, usually on the max or near max elastomer. Never had the Redshift give me anything I'd describe as side to side play on my dropbar setup. Absolutely zero negative impact to steering the bike. This is both on regular gravel riding and lift access singletrack. That said, stem suspension does not improve handling like a suspension fork. It doesn't keep the front wheel planted when going over bumps. Bumps still cause the while bike to move. The stem just improves comfort at the hand contact point. That comfort might mean your *ability* to steer and control the bike is better. That comfort also means you can ride longer before your hands get tired. Just don't confuse that comfort with the type of improved handling gained from suspension on the wheel. Or running wider and lower pressure tires.
